Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: A home loan repayment is due in two months, and the parent needs to prepare for it
Expectation2: Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the volunteer coordinator
Situation2: The coordinator emailed a brief suggestion about organizing supplies a different way if time allows.
Story:
I sat at the kitchen table, my laptop open to the family budget spreadsheet. The numbers glared at me—our home loan repayment was due in two months, and every dollar counted. I needed to find ways to save, maybe even pick up extra shifts at work. My mind buzzed with worry about keeping us afloat, about making sure my kids never felt the weight of my anxiety.

Just then, my phone chimed. It was an email from the volunteer coordinator at the food pantry. She’d sent a brief suggestion: if I had time during my next shift, could I reorganize the supply shelves according to a new system? She said it would help everyone, but only if I could manage it. I knew the pantry relied on volunteers to keep things running smoothly, and I wanted to do my part. But the thought of spending extra time there—time I could use to work more hours or plan our finances—made my chest tighten.

I stared at the email, torn between the needs of my family and the expectations of the volunteer team, feeling the pressure of both roles closing in.
